description: From Latin senātor, ultimately from senex (“old”).

entries.meaning: A member, normally elected, in the house or chamber of a legislature called a senate, as, for instance, the legislatures of the United States and Canada.
examples: It was disbanded when Derrick was only six, after that grouchy old ultra-Libertarian Senator Timothy de Illy made “welfare hotel for Third-World nations” a household catchphrase.

entries.meaning: (dated) A member of any legislative body or parliament, particularly the British Parliament.
(historical) A member of the ancient Roman Senate.
(historical) A member of a governing council in other states in the ancient world.
A member of the ruler’s council or governing council in general, a leading statesman.
